trans-unit.source: Sends simulated keystrokes to the active window.

seg-source.mrk: Sends simulated keystrokes to the active window.

target.mrk: Sends simulated keystrokes to the active window.

trans-unit.source: The sequence of keys to send.

seg-source.mrk: The sequence of keys to send.

target.mrk: The sequence of keys to send.

trans-unit.source: $SEND_DEFAULT (0) = Text contains special characters like + and ! to indicate SHIFT and ALT key-presses (default).

seg-source.mrk: $SEND_DEFAULT (0) = Text contains special characters like + and !
to indicate SHIFT and ALT key-presses (default).

target.mrk: $SEND_DEFAULT (0) = Text contains special characters like + and !
to indicate SHIFT and ALT key-presses (default).

trans-unit.source: See the Appendix for some tips on using Send(). AutoIt can send all ASCII and Extended ASCII characters (0-255). To send UNICODE characters you must use the "ASC" option and the code of the character you wish to send (see {ASC} at the bottom of the table below).

seg-source.mrk: See the Appendix for some tips on using Send().
AutoIt can send all ASCII and Extended ASCII characters (0-255).
To send UNICODE characters you must use the "ASC" option and the code of the character you wish to send (see {ASC} at the bottom of the table below).

target.mrk: See the Appendix for some tips on using Send().
AutoIt can send all ASCII and Extended ASCII characters (0-255).
To send UNICODE characters you must use the "ASC" option and the code of the character you wish to send (see {ASC} at the bottom of the table below).

trans-unit.source: The "Send()" command syntax is similar to that of ScriptIt and the Visual Basic "SendKeys" command. Characters are sent as written with the exception of the following characters:

seg-source.mrk: The "Send()" command syntax is similar to that of ScriptIt and the Visual Basic "SendKeys" command.
Characters are sent as written with the exception of the following characters:

target.mrk: The "Send()" command syntax is similar to that of ScriptIt and the Visual Basic "SendKeys" command.
Characters are sent as written with the exception of the following characters:

trans-unit.source: This tells AutoIt to send an ALT keystroke, therefore Send("This is text!a") would send the keys "This is text" and then press "ALT+a".

seg-source.mrk: This tells AutoIt to send an ALT keystroke, therefore Send("This is text!a") would send the keys "This is text" and then press "ALT+a".

target.mrk: This tells AutoIt to send an ALT keystroke, therefore Send("This is text!a") would send the keys "This is text" and then press "ALT+a".

trans-unit.source: N.B. Some programs are very choosy about capital letters and ALT keys, i.e., "!A" is different from "!a". The first says ALT+SHIFT+A, the second is ALT+a. If in doubt, use lowercase!

seg-source.mrk: Some programs are very choosy about capital letters and ALT keys, i.e.,
The first says ALT+SHIFT+A, the second is ALT+a.

target.mrk: Some programs are very choosy about capital letters and ALT keys, i.e.,
The first says ALT+SHIFT+A, the second is ALT+a.

trans-unit.source: This tells AutoIt to send a SHIFT keystroke; therefore, Send("Hell+o") would send the text "HellO". Send("!+a") would send "ALT+SHIFT+a".

seg-source.mrk: This tells AutoIt to send a SHIFT keystroke; therefore, Send("Hell+o") would send the text "HellO".

target.mrk: This tells AutoIt to send a SHIFT keystroke; therefore, Send("Hell+o") would send the text "HellO".

trans-unit.source: This tells AutoIt to send a CONTROL keystroke; therefore, Send("^!a") would send "CTRL+ALT+a".

seg-source.mrk: This tells AutoIt to send a CONTROL keystroke; therefore, Send("^!a") would send "CTRL+ALT+a".

target.mrk: This tells AutoIt to send a CONTROL keystroke; therefore, Send("^!a") would send "CTRL+ALT+a".

trans-unit.source: N.B. Some programs are very choosy about capital letters and CTRL keys, i.e., "^A" is different from "^a". The first says CTRL+SHIFT+A, the second is CTRL+a. If in doubt, use lowercase!

seg-source.mrk: Some programs are very choosy about capital letters and CTRL keys, i.e.,
The first says CTRL+SHIFT+A, the second is CTRL+a.

target.mrk: Some programs are very choosy about capital letters and CTRL keys, i.e.,
The first says CTRL+SHIFT+A, the second is CTRL+a.

trans-unit.source: The hash now sends a Windows keystroke; therefore, Send("#r") would send Win+r which launches the Run() dialog box.

seg-source.mrk: The hash now sends a Windows keystroke; therefore, Send("#r") would send Win+r which launches the Run() dialog box.

target.mrk: The hash now sends a Windows keystroke; therefore, Send("#r") would send Win+r which launches the Run() dialog box.

trans-unit.source: You can set SendCapslockMode to make CAPS LOCK disabled at the start of a Send() operation and restored upon completion.

seg-source.mrk: You can set SendCapslockMode to make CAPS LOCK disabled at the start of a Send() operation and restored upon completion.

target.mrk: You can set SendCapslockMode to make CAPS LOCK disabled at the start of a Send() operation and restored upon completion.

trans-unit.source: However, if a user is holding down the Shift key when a Send() function begins, text may be sent in uppercase.

seg-source.mrk: However, if a user is holding down the Shift key when a Send() function begins, text may be sent in uppercase.

target.mrk: However, if a user is holding down the Shift key when a Send() function begins, text may be sent in uppercase.

trans-unit.source: One workaround is to Send("{SHIFTDOWN}{SHIFTUP}") before the other Send() operations.

seg-source.mrk: One workaround is to Send("{SHIFTDOWN}{SHIFTUP}") before the other Send() operations.

target.mrk: One workaround is to Send("{SHIFTDOWN}{SHIFTUP}") before the other Send() operations.

trans-unit.source: Certain keyboards as the Czech keyboard sends different characters when using the Shift Key or with CAPS LOCK enabled while sending a character. Due to the send AutoIt implementation the CAPS LOCKed character will be sent as a Shifted character so it will not work.

seg-source.mrk: Certain keyboards as the Czech keyboard sends different characters when using the Shift Key or with CAPS LOCK enabled while sending a character.
Due to the send AutoIt implementation the CAPS LOCKed character will be sent as a Shifted character so it will not work.

target.mrk: Certain keyboards as the Czech keyboard sends different characters when using the Shift Key or with CAPS LOCK enabled while sending a character.
Due to the send AutoIt implementation the CAPS LOCKed character will be sent as a Shifted character so it will not work.

trans-unit.source: No key is sent if the count is zero allowing the count to be set programatically:

trans-unit.source: Send("{M " & $iCount & "}")    ;Presses the M key as many times as set in the $iCount variable

trans-unit.source: When running a script on a remote computer through a program as psexec (www.sysinternals.com) or beyondexec (www.beyondlogic.org) it is necessary, specially when sending strokes to a program launch by the script with a Run() function, to use ControlSend() or other ControlXXX functions to directly communicate with the control. Send() even with Opt("SendAttachMode", 1) will not work.

seg-source.mrk: When running a script on a remote computer through a program as psexec (www.sysinternals.com) or beyondexec (www.beyondlogic.org) it is necessary, specially when sending strokes to a program launch by the script with a Run() function, to use ControlSend() or other ControlXXX functions to directly communicate with the control.
Send() even with Opt("SendAttachMode", 1) will not work.

target.mrk: When running a script on a remote computer through a program as psexec (www.sysinternals.com) or beyondexec (www.beyondlogic.org) it is necessary, specially when sending strokes to a program launch by the script with a Run() function, to use ControlSend() or other ControlXXX functions to directly communicate with the control.
Send() even with Opt("SendAttachMode", 1) will not work.

trans-unit.source: Using the -s mode when submitting can help to have better rights on the remote computer.

seg-source.mrk: Using the -s mode when submitting can help to have better rights on the remote computer.

target.mrk: Using the -s mode when submitting can help to have better rights on the remote computer.

trans-unit.source: Opt("SendKeyDelay",...) alters the the length of the brief pause in between sent keystrokes.

seg-source.mrk: Opt("SendKeyDelay",...) alters the the length of the brief pause in between sent keystrokes.

target.mrk: Opt("SendKeyDelay",...) alters the the length of the brief pause in between sent keystrokes.

trans-unit.source: Opt("SendKeyDownDelay",...) alters the length of time a key is held down before being released during a keystroke.

seg-source.mrk: Opt("SendKeyDownDelay",...) alters the length of time a key is held down before being released during a keystroke.

target.mrk: Opt("SendKeyDownDelay",...) alters the length of time a key is held down before being released during a keystroke.

trans-unit.source: Set both "SendKeyDelay" and "SendKeyDownDelay" to 0 to remove all delays when sending keystrokes. This may be required under certain circumstances, for example, when locking the system ("#l") it may be necessary to remove the delays in order to prevent the WIN key from being stuck down.

seg-source.mrk: Set both "SendKeyDelay" and "SendKeyDownDelay" to 0 to remove all delays when sending keystrokes.
This may be required under certain circumstances, for example, when locking the system ("#l") it may be necessary to remove the delays in order to prevent the WIN key from being stuck down.

target.mrk: Set both "SendKeyDelay" and "SendKeyDownDelay" to 0 to remove all delays when sending keystrokes.
This may be required under certain circumstances, for example, when locking the system ("#l") it may be necessary to remove the delays in order to prevent the WIN key from being stuck down.
